user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_queue_auth_fail_response:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_queue_auth_fail_response (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                              const char *realm,
                              const char *opaque,
                              struct MHD_Response *response,
                              int signal_stale)
{
  return MHD_queue_auth_fail_response2 (connection,
                                        realm,
                                        opaque,
                                        response,
                                        signal_stale,
                                        MHD_DIGEST_ALG_MD5);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_queue_auth_fail_response:
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_queue_auth_fail_response2 (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                               const char *realm,
                               const char *opaque,
                               struct MHD_Response *response,
                               int signal_stale,
                               enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgorithm algo)
{
  enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 algo3;

  if (MHD_DIGEST_ALG_MD5 == algo)
    algo3 = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_MD5;
  else if (MHD_DIGEST_ALG_SHA256 == algo)
    algo3 = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_SHA256;
  else if (MHD_DIGEST_ALG_AUTO == algo)
    algo3 = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_ANY_NON_SESSION;
  else
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Wrong algo value.\n")); /* API violation! */

  return MHD_queue_auth_required_response3 (connection, realm, opaque,
                                            NULL, response, signal_stale,
                                            MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_QOP_AUTH,
                                            algo3,
                                            0, 0);
}
...
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_queue_auth_required_response3 (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                   const char *realm,
                                   const char *opaque,
                                   const char *domain,
                                   struct MHD_Response *response,
                                   int signal_stale,
                                   enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiQOP mqop,
                                   enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 malgo3,
                                   int userhash_support,
                                   int prefer_utf8)
{
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;
  char *buf_ptr;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  buf_ptr = NULL;
  digest_setup_zero (&da);
  ret = queue_auth_required_response3_inner (connection,
                                             realm,
                                             opaque,
                                             domain,
                                             response,
                                             signal_stale,
                                             mqop,
                                             malgo3,
                                             userhash_support,
                                             prefer_utf8,
                                             &buf_ptr,
                                             &da);
  digest_deinit (&da);
  if (NULL != buf_ptr)
    free (buf_ptr);
  return ret;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
else
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Wrong algo value.\n")); /* API violation! */
explanation:
I focused on fragments that can affect reachability: (1) the public wrapper MHD_queue_auth_fail_response always passes MHD_DIGEST_ALG_MD5 to the underlying function — if this wrapper is the only API entry used in the project, the other branches of the algorithm-selection if/else could be effectively unreachable and should be checked. (2) The if/else chain in MHD_queue_auth_fail_response2 and the else branch invoking MHD_PANIC are suspicious because their interaction with the definition/behavior of MHD_PANIC (e.g. whether it is noreturn or returns) affects reachability and the initialization/use of algo3. If MHD_PANIC does not return, subsequent code on that path is deliberately unreachable; if it does return, algo3 may be used uninitialized — both situations warrant investigation. (3) The return that passes algo3 into MHD_queue_auth_required_response3 is included because it may use algo3 even if an unexpected algo value occurred (depending on MHD_PANIC semantics).

I did not mark other fragments for investigation because they contain standard, clearly reachable control flow: digest_setup_zero/digest_deinit and the call to queue_auth_required_response3_inner are normal call/return sequences, the conditional free (if (NULL != buf_ptr) free(buf_ptr)) is a normal conditional cleanup (not inherently unreachable), and there are no other unconditional returns, infinite loops, or dead-code constructs in the supplied code. The only locations where reachability is ambiguous or potentially violated are the algorithm-selection branches, the panic invocation, and the wrapper that forces a single enum value.
